questionList.qu: What is the definition for Enthalpy of Formation?
questionList.a1: The Enthalpy change when a compound in its standard state is formed from its constituent elements in their standard states, under standard conditions.
questionList.a2: The Enthalpy change when one mole of a compound is formed from its constituent elements in their standard states, under standard conditions.
questionList.a3: The Enthalpy change when one mole of a compound in its standard state is formed from its constituent elements in their standard states.
questionList.a4: The Enthalpy change when one mole of a compound in its standard state is formed from its constituent elements in their standard states, under standard conditions
questionList.solution: The Enthalpy change when one mole of a compound in its standard state is formed from its constituent elements in their standard states, under standard conditions

questionList.qu: What is the definition of enthalpy of combustion?
questionList.a1: The enthalpy change when one mole of the compound is burned completely in oxygen, and with everything in its standard state.
questionList.a2: The enthalpy change when one mole of the compound is burned completely in oxygen which is in standard state under standard conditions, and with everything in its standard state.
questionList.a3: The enthalpy change when one mole of the compound is burned completely in oxygen under standard conditions, and with everything in its standard state.
questionList.a4: The enthalpy change when one mole of the compound is burned completely in oxygen under standard conditions.
questionList.solution: The enthalpy change when one mole of the compound is burned completely in oxygen which is in standard state under standard conditions, and with everything in its standard state.

questionList.qu: What is the definition of Enthalpy of Neutralization?
questionList.a1: The standard enthalpy change of neutralization is the enthalpy change when an acid and an alkali react together under standard conditions to produce on mole of water.
questionList.a2: The standard enthalpy change of neutralization is the enthalpy change when solutions of an acid and an alkali react together under standard conditions to produce on mole of water.
questionList.a3: The standard enthalpy change of neutralization is the enthalpy change when solutions of an acid and an alkali react together to produce on mole of water.
questionList.a4: The standard enthalpy change of neutralization is the enthalpy change when solutions of an acid and an alkali react together under standard conditions to produce water.
questionList.solution: The standard enthalpy change of neutralization is the enthalpy change when solutions of an acid and an alkali react together under standard conditions to produce on mole of water.

questionList.qu: What is Specific Heat Capacity?
questionList.a1: The amount of heat it takes to raise the temperature of a substance by 1 degree.
questionList.a2: The amount of energy it takes to raise the temperature of a substance.
questionList.a3: The amount of energy it takes to raise the temperature of a substance by 1 degree.
questionList.a4: The amount of mechanical energy it takes to raise the temperature of a substance by 1 degree.
questionList.solution: The amount of energy it takes to raise the temperature of a substance by 1 degree.

questionList.qu: What is the definition of bond enthalpy?
questionList.a1: The enthalpy change when 1 mole of covalent bonds, in a sold molecule, are broken under standard conditions.
questionList.a2: The enthalpy change when 1 mole of covalent bonds, in a aqueous molecule, are broken under standard conditions.
questionList.a3: The enthalpy change when 1 mole of covalent bonds, in a gaseous molecule, are broken under standard conditions.
questionList.a4: The enthalpy change when covalent bonds, in a gaseous molecule, are broken under standard conditions.
questionList.solution: The enthalpy change when 1 mole of covalent bonds, in a gaseous molecule, are broken under standard conditions.

questionList.qu: What is the definition of average bond enthalpy?
questionList.a1: The average amount of energy required to break 10 moles of covalent bonds, in a gaseous molecule under standard conditions. 'Average' refers to the fact that the bond enthalpy is different in the different molecules and so the value quoted is the average amount of energy to break a particular bond in a range on compounds.
